poem:
"Doughnuts in the Morning Sun"

Sweet circles of sunlight, a reward restyled,
Addictive perhaps, as she drove the extra mile.
Compulsion, you say, but let me muse,
Are not all crucibles, bitter or sweet, ours to choose?
In the fragile layers of a Krispy Kreme,
Lie tales of temptation and diabetic dreams,
For even in peril's profoundest abyss,
There is no villain quite like bliss.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Your brain sees sugar as a reward. But does that mean it’s addictive? Psychologist Ashley Gearhardt remembers one type 2 diabetes patient who acknowledged that eating pillowy Krispy Kreme doughnuts is devastatingly bad for her. Knowing that the donuts could worsen her disease didn’t stop her from driving out of her way to secure a box of the sweets. “Clearly, compulsivity is happening,” said Gearhardt, a University of Michigan professor and one of the creators". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
